author: Francesca Gillett
title: London Bridge station: Commuters warned of major disruption on trains for rest of evening
text:
Tuesday 7 March 2017 16:20 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard London Bridge station was evacuated after the security scare on Tuesday afternoon. @rhysdurham 
Rail passengers are being warned of major disruption on the trains tonight after a security scare at London Bridge. 
London Bridge rail and Tube station was put on lockdown on Tuesday afternoon after a security alert sparked by a suspicious vehicle nearby. 
Police cordoned off a large area and some buildings were evacuated as crowds took to the streets in confusion. 
All trains to and from Charing Cross, Cannon Street and Waterloo East were temporarily suspended and Southeastern Railway urged passengers to take alternative routes. Crowds of people described 'chaos' after the station and nearby buildings were evacuated. (@rhysdurham) 
Despite the incident being stood down at around 3.30pm, commuters were warned disruption was likely to continue on the trains throughout the rest of the evening. 
Some trains to and from Cannon Street and Charing Cross are still set to be diverted or cancelled, Southeastern Railway said. 
In a string of tweets the rail operator said: “London Bridge station has reopened but major disruption will continue for the rest of this evening. Please check before you travel. #LondonBridge - station has re-opened but major disruption will continue for the rest of this evening. Please check before you travel. — Southeastern (@Se_Railway) March 7, 2017 
“Although the station has now reopened, disruption will continue from Cannon Street and Charing Cross for some time.” 
Passengers are being encouraged to use London Victoria, Blackfriars or St Pancras to reduce the pressure on the service. 
Tube users reported queues at London Bridge station as it reopened. 
A Met Police spokesman said: “We were called to a security alert in London Bridge street at 1.40pm. The bus station and part of the rail station were evacuated as a precaution." More about:
